Contrast API Reference¶

Module: Framework¶

Contains functions for building and running an experiment with parameters defined in the experiment.cfg file.

framework.framework.build_experiment(experiment_name='', build_stimulus_func=None, model_params=[], experiment_params=[], stimulus_params=[], **params)[source]¶
framework.framework.build_operators(offsets, viewing_distance=22.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282, field_height=100, field_width=100)[source]¶

NOTE: Ji and Javg as filters should each sum to one

Framework Library¶

Contains functions that are independent of any specific experiment.

framework.library.get_correct_coords(start_x=0, viewing_distance=12.0, field_height=10, field_width=10, pixel_width=0.282, pixel_height=0.282, **config)[source]¶

returns the coords in terms of degree of visual angle converts Euclidean to Polar coordinates based on a fixation point, viewing distance, and a window size polar coordinate conversion:

  • r = np.sqrt(np.square(x) + np.square(y))
  • th = np.arctan2(y,x)

log-polar coordinate conversion based on degrees of visual angle from fixation:

  • r = np.rad2deg(np.arctan2(np.sqrt(np.square(x) + np.square(y)),viewing_distance*25.4))
framework.library.get_degrees_at_pixels(pixels=10, viewing_distance=24.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282)[source]¶

pixels - if fovea is centered on an image, pixels is half the image width in pixels returns - half the viewing_angle

framework.library.get_image_width_in_degrees(image_width=100, viewing_distance=24.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282)[source]¶

image_width is size of entire in pixels returns: degrees to span the entire image

framework.library.get_image_width_in_pixels(degrees=1.0, viewing_distance=24.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282)[source]¶

degrees is viewing angle of the entire image returns: num of pixels that span the entire image

framework.library.get_pixels_at_degrees(degrees=1.0, viewing_distance=24.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282)[source]¶

degrees - if fovea is centered on an image, degrees is half the viewing angle returns: pixels - if fovea is centered on an image, pixels is half the image width in pixels

framework.library.get_sigma_map(start_x=0, field_height=100, field_width=100, viewing_distance=12.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282, debug=False)[source]¶

For each point on the image (image_height x image_width) returns the sigma associated with each point due to the offset from the fovea of the image. The average of all the sigmas may be used as an approximation to the full set of all sigmas. Each sigma is used as the basis for creating the J operator which is the weighting of all the pixels given one pixel as a focal point.

Parameters:start_x – is in degrees of visual angle
Returns:an entire field_height x field_width array of sigma values
framework.library.get_viewing_distance_to_span_image(image_width=20, degree_span=1.0, screen_pixel_size=0.282)[source]¶

degrees is viewing angle of the entire image image_width is size of entire in pixels

Experiments Library¶

Contains functions that are used by all specific experiments.

framework.experiments.library.compute_response(df1, compute_error=False, est_max=-1.0, sigma_t=5.0, upper_limit=0.85, lower_limit=0.0)[source]¶

returns df,mean_target,sigma_target,K

Parameters:
  • df1 – the dataframe used to compute responses, see note 1 below
  • compute_error – if True, responses will be 1-response
  • est_max – method used to estimate the maximum background sigma
  • sigma_t – divisor for sigma_t
Returns:

df,mean_target,sigma_target,K

Note

1: where df1 is of the form:

# where df1 is of the form:
offset                5         10        15        20
flank_distance                                        
 -1.00           0.009318  0.010185  0.011334  0.012599
  0.05           0.010523  0.009813  0.010544  0.012038
  0.10           0.013262  0.012097  0.011458  0.011655
  0.15           0.013903  0.013449  0.013085  0.012946
  0.20           0.013882  0.013690  0.013561  0.013528
  0.30           0.013623  0.013646  0.014068  0.014614
  0.40           0.013587  0.013523  0.013959  0.014692
  0.60           0.013583  0.013481  0.013832  0.014533
framework.experiments.library.decision_func(df, target_contrast=0.027, sigma=0.05, K=5.0, upper_limit=0.85, lower_limit=0.0)[source]¶

Computes the result of applying the descision function to all the contrast values in the dataframe df.

The decision function computes the difference of gaussians applied to the contrast values in df as follows:

decision =

Parameters:
  • df – the contast values for the experiment as a dataframe
  • target_contrast – the contrast value for the target-alone condition
  • sigma – the std. dev. of the target-alone contrast
  • K – mulitplier for target+distractor sigma
  • upper_limit – upper_limit for the descision function which normally is 1.0
  • lower_limit – lower_limit for the descision function which normally is 0.0
Returns:

result of decision function applied to dataframe df
